In the seventh Title are explained the so called ‘actiones adiectitiae qualitatis,’ by which the Praetor had tempered the inequitable doctrine of the civil law that a master or paterfamilias, though entitled to all benedt under the contracts oi his slaves or children in power, could in no case be sued upon them. By the actiones quod iussu, exer- citoria, and institoria the superior became liable in solidum whenever it could be shown that he had directed or authorized the contract.
